title: How to make the perfect roast chicken
summary: The perfect roast chicken is a juicy, flavoursome chicken roasted to perfection. Rely on a trusted source of meat thatâ€™s free-range and organic if possible. Dry-brining will help your skin to crisp up during the roasting process. Roasted garlic is delicious, and the flavour will permeate your chicken with a subtle, but delicious aroma. Roast vegetables and aromatics can be roasted with your chicken for a delicious and nutritious side dish that goes perfectly with chicken. Flavour balance with herbs and spices, such as spices, also has its own natural flavour.

In order to make the perfect roast chicken, it\u2019s important to start with the right ingredients. Rely on a trusted source of meat that\u2019s free-range and organic if possible. Your roast chicken will taste miles better than the factory-farmed alternative!`),mdx("p",null,"When it comes to flavourings and seasonings, roast chicken is very versatile. You can add almost anything to it. Popular options include:"),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Herbs: Rosemary and sage make fantastic additions to roast chicken. If you want to try something a little different, try adding some orange zest or a few sprigs of thyme.")),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Spices: Chili powder, cayenne pepper, paprika, garam masala, or turmeric can all add a kick of flavour to your roast chicken.")),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Garlic: Roasted garlic is delicious, and the flavour will permeate your chicken with a subtle, but delicious aroma."))),mdx("h2",null,"Pro tip: dry-brining your chicken"),mdx("p",null,"If you have time, consider dry-brining your chicken. This means sprinkling your chicken with salt and letting it sit in the fridge for a few hours before roasting (or at least 30 minutes!). The salt will draw out moisture through osmosis and your chicken will retain more of its natural flavours."),mdx("p",null,"Dry-brining will also help your skin to crisp up during the roasting process, meaning you will have more control over the end result and the amount of fat that drips into your roasting tray."),mdx("p",null,"A simple dry rub will do the trick. You can use one you\u2019ve concocted yourself or purchase a pre-made dry rub from your local grocery store."),mdx("h2",null,"Aromatics and herbs"),mdx("p",null,`Aromatics and herbs are what will give your roast chicken its distinct flavour.
Use a combination of fresh herbs and dried herbs if you enjoy the flavour they impart better.`),mdx("p",null,"Fresh herbs, like thyme, rosemary, and sage, will retain their flavour and taste better when you roast your chicken than dried herbs, so choose fresh if you can."),mdx("p",null,"Dried herbs, on the other hand, are a great way to add flavour without having to chop up any fresh herbs. If you\u2019re using dried herbs, be sure to use half as much as you would fresh herbs."),mdx("p",null,"If you want to get really fancy, certain vegetables and aromatics can be roasted with your chicken for a delicious and nutritious side dish that goes perfectly with chicken. Try this recipe for roasted root vegetables for a simple and tasty side dish."),mdx("h2",null,"The Chicken Broth"),mdx("p",null,"A good chicken broth is a fantastic addition to a roast chicken. If you have time, you can make your own chicken broth and save it in the freezer for future use. Alternatively, you can use a store-bought organic chicken broth, like this organic chicken broth that you can purchase online."),mdx("p",null,"You can use the broth while your chicken is roasting, or you can reserve some of it to use as a sauce after your chicken is fully cooked."),mdx("h2",null,"Timing is everything: roasting times for chicken"),mdx("p",null,`When it comes to roast chicken, timing is everything. You want to get your chicken in the oven quickly, but not too quickly or it will burn.
Combining heat and time is how we achieve the perfect roast chicken.`),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Heat: You want to put your chicken in a hot oven, but not too hot. You want to preheat your oven to around 400 degrees Fahrenheit. If you are using a gas oven, put the chicken in the oven for a minute before you turn it on to let it warm up. If you are using an electric oven, you want to put the chicken in before it has fully heated up.")),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("p",{parentName:"li"},"Time: The key here is to not overcook your chicken. You want to cook it until it is fully cooked. The standard cooking time for a roast chicken is 20 to 25 minutes. If you are cooking a larger chicken, increase the time by 5 minutes."))),mdx("h2",null,"Flavour balance with herbs and spices"),mdx("p",null,"While chicken can take on many different flavours, such as herbs and spices, it also has its own natural flavour that isn\u2019t always present in other meats. You want to make sure to maintain a balance between the flavours you are adding to your chicken. If the herbs you are using are overpowering, then it can make your chicken taste bitter."),mdx("p",null,"If you want to make sure you are achieving the perfect flavour balance, you can rub your chicken with an herb and oil mixture before roasting it. This is a great way to coat your chicken evenly."),mdx("h2",null,"Try this delicious Moroccan Spice Mix"),mdx("p",null,"If you are looking for a new flavour to try out on your next roast chicken, try a Moroccan spice mix. It will add a hint of spicy heat and rich flavour that pairs perfectly with roasted chicken. This recipe calls for cinnamon, paprika, coriander, cumin, turmeric, ginger, and black pepper."),mdx("p",null,"For an easy way to make your own spice mix, try this recipe. You can store your spice mix in an airtight jar for future use. It will keep for a long time without losing flavour."),mdx("p",null,"For a quick and easy recipe that uses this Moroccan spice mix, try this chicken with roasted potatoes and carrots."),mdx("h2",null,"Summing up"),mdx("p",null,"This recipe for roast chicken is easy to make and full of flavour, making it a great option for a family dinner or an easy dinner for two. The best part is that it\u2019s great for leftovers. Simply store your chicken and potatoes in the fridge for a few days. Then, throw them in the oven for a quick and easy dinner."),mdx("p",null,"When you make the perfect roast chicken, you don't need to look any further for dinner inspiration. Containing all the nutrients you need, it's also packed with flavour and can be served with a variety of accompaniments. Whether you're cooking for one or hosting dinner for friends, this is a great go-to meal."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Think about it: Great home cooks know how to make leftovers taste even better. They use them to create new and different meals that everyone will love, instead of eating the same thing again and again until they can\u2019t stand it any more.
That\u2019s why we\u2019ve come up with this list of the best recipes for using up leftover cooked chicken. These recipes are quick and easy to make, but they also tick all the right boxes in terms of taste, nutrition and ease of preparation. In other words, not only do they all use up your leftovers in a delicious way, but they also make your life easier so you won\u2019t feel like you have to avoid cooking another chicken dish again just because you\u2019re fed up with leftovers!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

After all, who doesn\u2019t like a hot, cheesy, gooey personal-sized pie? Luckily, thanks to rising demand for home delivery and takeout services as well as growing interest in gourmet cooking and home-delivery meal kit services such as Blue Apron, home-cooked pizzas are easier than ever to make at home. Unfortunately, many people also associate salads with bad food because they\u2019ve had so many disappointing experiences eating them in the past. It\u2019s a bleak time of year that can be difficult to get through. However, there are some upsides to it, too. Even famous athletes are getting in on the action. Superstars like LeBron James and Tom Brady are known for their high performance on game day as much as their off-season diet. The only problem with all of these healthy eating fads is that they can feel like a big challenge to follow every single day. But what if you could make it easier?
It\u2019t not crazy to think you can eat healthier every day. After all, you aren\u2019t permanently locked into an unhealthy lifestyle. Your habits change over time, which means your diet can too! You just need a plan to get there, which is why we\u2019ve outlined five simple tips that will help you eat healthier every day without feeling like a chore.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Comfort Food Recipes to Warm Your Soul

Who can resist the wholesome aroma of a slow-cooked dish? Not us!
These dishes are filled with rich and savory ingredients that warm you from the inside out. They\u2019re also easy to make in large batches, which means you can enjoy them for dinner for several nights in a row without getting bored. And because these comforting meals are easy to double or triple, they\u2019re also excellent ideas for homesick college students or anyone who misses mom\u2019s home cooking. So, don your stretchy pants and get ready to dive into these 15 yummy comfort food recipes this season has to offer\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Maybe it\u2019s time to amp things up a notch. A good diet is essential to a healthy life, and with so many different diets being promoted these days, it can be hard to separate fact from fiction. When it comes to nutrition, there are so many factors to take into account. You might know that vitamins and minerals are important and that fats, proteins, and carbs all play an important role in your diet. But how do you actually make sure that your diet reflects those principles? Here are some tips and tricks on how you can make your diet more nutritious:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Is Organic Really Worth the Extra Cost?

intro.compiledSource:
var d=Object.defineProperty,m=Object.defineProperties;var y=Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptors;var a=Object.getOwnPropertySymbols;var i=Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty,h=Object.prototype.propertyIsEnumerable;var s=(t,e,o)=>e in t?d(t,e,{enumerable:!0,configurable:!0,writable:!0,value:o}):t[e]=o,r=(t,e)=>{for(var o in e||(e={}))i.call(e,o)&&s(t,o,e[o]);if(a)for(var o of a(e))h.call(e,o)&&s(t,o,e[o]);return t},c=(t,e)=>m(t,y(e));var g=(t,e)=>{var o={};for(var n in t)i.call(t,n)&&e.indexOf(n)<0&&(o[n]=t[n]);if(t!=null&&a)for(var n of a(t))e.indexOf(n)<0&&h.call(t,n)&&(o[n]=t[n]);return o};const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent(o){var n=o,{components:t}=n,e=g(n,["components"]);return mdx(MDXLayout,c(r(r({},layoutProps),e),{components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"}),mdx("p",null,`You can\u2019t open a magazine or social media feed these days without seeing something about the organic food movement. In fact, the organic food market is growing faster than any other segment of the food industry. According to the Organic Trade Association, sales of organic foods increased by almost 10% in 2017 alone. And given that more and more consumers are becoming aware of what they\u2019re eating and where it comes from, that isn\u2019t going to change anytime soon. Which begs the question: Are all those new organic options worth it? Do they really taste better than conventional alternatives? Are they healthier for you? And most importantly, is the cost worth it?
If you read through all the information on different types of organic foods and their benefits, you might be feeling a little overwhelmed right now. That\u2019s totally normal! But don\u2019t fret\u2014we have you covered with everything you need to know about whether or not organic is worth its hefty price tag.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Nutrient Dense Superfoods That Improve Overall Health

They also tend to be high in antioxidants, fiber, and other phytonutrients that help protect your body from free radicals and diseases. These healthy, natural foods can be found in almost any corner of the globe. Many indigenous cultures eat these as staples because of their abundant benefits for the human body.
Superfoods generally have impressive quantities of some or many nutrients, such as carotenoids (vitamin A), flavonoids, vitamins C and E, or omega-3 fatty acids (ALA). There are many types of superfoods; here is a list of 20 worth adding to your diet:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
